text.p: Lithuanian newspapers carried the following reports in their Tuesday editions. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy:

- Three shops in the chain of British-owned Vision Express glass and contact lens retailer were hit by explosions on Sunday night. The blasts occurred simultaneosly in Vilnius, Kaunas and Panevezhys and police officials have little doubt the attack was well planned and co-ordinated.
- Ukrainian President Leonid Kuchma started a two-day official visit to Lithuania on Monday.

- A visit last week by Deutsche Morgan Grenfell representative Piotr Konwicki showed the investment giant is interested in coming to Lithuania. Lithuanian Investment Agency official Kestutis Stankevicius did not want to name concrete sums DMG would like to invest but pointed out that the bank was not interested in projects worth less than $5 million.

- Lithuanian President Algirdas Brazauskas signed a decree and appointed MP Romualdas Ozolas as head of a working group that will investigate government corruption and abuses of power. The group will draw up plans for a "National Investigation Bureau" to investigate how state credits have been spent, the banking crisis and corruption of public servants.

- U.S. investment bank Merill Lynch and oil company Mazheikiu Nafta signed a letter of intent for a $19 million loan and the agreement is to be signed next week after the finance ministry has approved it.
- Lithuanian President Algirdas Brazauskas called September 23 - the day of Jewish Genocide - one of the saddest in the calendar of memorable dates.

- A Vilnius Court will on October 9 start trying former Communist Party officials accused of helping to organise the hardline crackdown against Lithuania's independence on January 13, 1991. President Algirdas Brazauskas and the chairman of parliament, Cheslovas Jurshenas, could be called as witnesses.

- Finance Minister Algimantas Krizinauskas and high ranking J.P. Morgan officials will sign a $75 million syndicated loan agreement today. The loan, led by JP Morgan, has LIBOR +2.25 basis points interest rate and has a one year plus one day maturity, lower and two-times longer than the first $33 million syndicated loan provided by J.P. Morgan in April.
- The Association of Meat Processors asks the Agricultural Ministry to allow it to import 2,000-3,000 tonnes of pork without the usual 30 percent customs duty.
